abstracts.cdata!:
The Azerbaijan Agricultural Development
            and Credit Project had a satisfactory outcome, is likely to
            be sustainable, and has a modest institutional development
            impact. The performances of the Borrower and the Bank are
            rated satisfactory. Lessons learned included the following:
            1) In order to manage complicated technical assistance
            effectively and efficiently, it is important to first
            develop a capacity and understanding within the Project
            Implementation Unit of the main features of technical
            assistance, and international best practice on the subject
            matter since the risk of failure due to poor technical
            assistance is great. 2) The Project needs to be selective in
            the number of monitoring indicators, progress indicators,
            Adaptable Program Lending triggers, and targets, etc., as
            management of the too complex monitoring system becomes a
            cumbersome and time-consuming project activity in itself. 3)
            For objectives that involve changing the mentality or
            attitude of Government agency personnel, projects need to
            include opportunities for gaining international experiences
            through study tours or conferences. 4) Advantages of a
            credit line managed by a third party with risk-sharing and
            co-financing arrangements include: (1) transparency of
            implementation; (2) careful screening of potential borrowers
            and thus high repayment rates; and (3) no Government or
            political influence. There are also disadvantages: (1) the
            desire to shift disbursement towards the end of the Project
            in order to minimize its own risk; (2) some initiatives are
            legitimate from the point of view of the co-financier as a
            commercial company, but are not in accord with the
            Project's philosophy or methodology.    The
            Project's implementation reconfirmed some of the usual
            lessons from many other projects, such as (1) a very
            complicated project design consisting of multiple activities
            should be avoided as it dilutes the focus on the most
            essential outcome the project attempts to achieve, and makes
            supervision and implementation extremely costly and time
            consuming; (2) preparation of the project design should not
            be short-cut, as any flows in the design ultimately
            undermine the quality of project implementation and
            achievements; and (3) expectations for implementation
            periods of conceptually innovative activities should be
            based on more realistic assumptions.
